summary: Pokemon Card of the Day #1509: Beartic (Emerging Powers #30)
title: Pokemon Card of the Day #1509: Beartic (Emerging Powers #30)
body:
Of the two Beartic in the Emerging Powers set, this one got all of the attention. This attention was due to Sheer Cold, which could prevent the Defending Pokemon from being able to attack during the opponent’s next turn without even requiring a coin flip to work. A couple of possibilities came up right away, with both Feraligatr Prime and Vileplume being mentioned as potential partners. Could Beartic live up to all the hype?

130 HP was really impressive for a Stage 1. This was a number expected on a Stage 2 and was actually enough to take big attacks like a Reshiram Blue Flare or Zekrom Bolt Strike if at full health. The Metal Weakness was one of the better ones to have. In the HGSS-On format, Cobalion showed up every once in a while, but that was about it. The BLW-On format had Cobalion EX but wasn’t where you’d want to use Beartic anyway. Blastoise had better partners than Beartic. The Retreat Cost here was 3, and that was high enough to require the use of a card such as Switch.

Sheer Cold wasn’t very strong, but it came with a big effect. 50 damage for a Water and 2 Colorless was really bad. Preventing the Defending Pokemon from attacking during your opponent’s next turn was incredible. It could be switched out of, which made Beartic pretty useless against decks using either Yanmega or Darkrai EX. For others, the effect could be a big problem since there were only so many switching cards to fit in a deck. You could try to lock those down by pairing Beartic with Vileplume, though a deck like that could be a bit slow to get going. The Feraligatr version was faster but didn’t have as hard of a lock, but both were going to try to use Sheer Cold as much as possible.

Icicle Crash was a bit expensive. 2 Water and 2 Colorless Energy for 80 damage didn’t stand out, though at least it wasn’t affected by Resistance which meant that any Grass-types out there weren’t quite as safe. This could get a KO in a Feraligatr deck if needed but required a lot of resources to use.

Beartic didn’t quite live up to all of the hype. It was solid with Feraligatr even if it wasn’t as efficient as what some other types had. The Vileplume version was tempting but could be out-sped by a lot of fast attackers. It was on the lower end of competitive and was borderline tournament-worthy despite these issues, at least until the Dark Explorers deck came out and brought along a huge surge of Darkrai EX. To be fair, Beartic was still pretty good for a Stage 1 in this era, so it wasn’t bad to try it if looking for something a bit different.

summary: i've just recently come into ownership (trainership?) of my own pokemon, a very-recently-evolved Bibarel. I've never really...
question: i've just recently come into ownership (trainership?) of my own pokemon, a very-recently-evolved Bibarel. I've never really spent a huge amount of time around pokemon before for personal reasons, and i'm wondering if there's anything important i need to know about pokemon care or Bibarels in particular?
answer:
Chew toys are the name of the game. They gnaw constantly, as their teeth do not ever stop growing. In addition to wood-based toys, providing a diet that consists of harder vegetables will also keep them occupied.

Bibarel are very restless creatures and yours will want to build a shelter for themself. I recommend providing material so that parts of your furniture are not used for this purpose. 

Keep in mind that Bibarel do not have great eyesight, as they are much more adapted to swimming underwater and spending time within their dark dams. Target training using specific images may stress out your Pokémon if you plan on training it to battle.

-Thea

blog.name: pokebiologist
blog.title: Pokémon Biology
blog.description: I'm Theodora, but you can call me Thea! I'm a Battle Girl turned Pokémon Researcher, and I'm excited to share my observations with you. Feel free to ask, submit, request, and share your own findings!

summary: Can we have a brief overview of military applications of pokemon and the ethical concerns thereof?
question: Can we have a brief overview of military applications of pokemon and the ethical concerns thereof?
answer:
Oh boy. I’m no historian, but I’ll do my best!
A long time ago, Pokémon were used pretty commonly in human conflicts, but this was when conflict was small-scale and didn’t involve very many people. Establishing formal rules about Pokémon battling systems was actually partly inspired by an overall desire to find a different way to resolve issues.

Currently, it is internationally considered a war crime to have a Pokémon use an attack on a human being during conflict. And within most regions, there are very serious consequences for doing so on a smaller scale. It often results in having your Pokémon taken away and re-homed, and being legally forbidden from owning Pokémon in the future.

Pokémon have been used in more recent wars, but in largely nonviolent roles. Their abilities to heal, spy, predict the future, and manipulate weather have been influential in many battles. 

Hope this was sufficient!

-Thea
